prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

para.paratext: Tag-along actions are very likely to be transferred, if at all, to the district where the previously transferred actions are pending. The reasons for this presumptive destination should be obvious. It is not a foregone conclusion, however, for the Panel can transfer the tag-along cases to a different district or to a different judge.

The Panel's awareness of the tag-along actions may prompt reconsideration of the desirability of having the transferee court continue the handling of the cases. Retransfer is not favored, however. The party seeking a new district has a difficult burden, however, and is not likely to have a different district assigned unless compelling reasons are brought to the attention of the Panel.[1]
The Panel has stated two of the reasons for not favoring retransfer motions:

In the past we have been extremely reluctant to retransfer litigation under Section 1407. This reluctance is founded on mainly two grounds: first, the question of the most appropriate transferee forum should not be relitigated every time another action is considered for inclusion in the centralized pretrial proceedings of a previously transferred litigation because it could destroy the effectiveness of Section 1407; and secondly, effort expended by the original transferee court in supervising the litigation would be wasted. These principles, especially the latter one, are certainly applicable here and, therefore, we see no reason to order retransfer.[2]

If the Panel does consider retransfer to be appropriate, it may schedule a separate hearing on that question. In one case where retransfer became potentially appropriate, the Panel is sued an order to show cause why retransfer should not be ordered and served it on all parties to the litigation.[3] This procedure offers specific notice to all parties that the Panel recognizes factors which might justify retransfer. The Panel granted retransfer in the Petroleum Products litigation, but specifically stated that it would be “a rare occurrence” for the grounds for retransfer in those cases to arise again.[4] In a later case the Panel determined that retransfer was justified because numerous actions had been filed since the original transfer decision and the alignment of the parties changed so that many favored retransfer. The Panel stated in that case:

While a sufficient showing has been made for us to conclude that the just and efficient conduct of this particular litigation can best be accomplished by transfer of all actions to the District of Connecticut, we reiterate our expectation that the coalescence of new circumstances and development sufficient to warrant retransfer of litigations will continue to occur only in the most extraordinary instances.[5]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
